Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Award.AbstractNarration:
One of the key features of the brain is how quickly and naturally it learns from experience -- not only factual information, but also abstract relationships and associations. Fire and flame burn; a sound like "mama" typically conjures up concepts of mother, comfort, and love. While recent advance in neuroscience have helped to uncover the basic brain processes that support everyday learning, this knowledge has not yet realized its potential to help people facing various clinical challenges. The goal of this project is to bring together neuroscientists who understand the neuroscience of learning, rehabilitation specialists who understand what kinds of problems individuals face, and computer scientists who can help create engaging training regiments that make it painless and even fun to undertake the often repetitious training required to support learning. The assembled team will support exchanges of pre- and post-doctoral trainees across different laboratories to jump-start collaborations, seed projects that support interdisciplinary research into engaging training paradigms, a web portal to disseminate results, and an annual scientific conference that brings together the diverse expertise necessary to create fun and interesting neural training programs. Immersive, active training programs can have beneficial effects on the brain, and can be harnessed to study the process of learning in motivated, engaged participants. Yet realizing this potential requires bringing together traditionally distinct research communities. Collaboration is needed among neuroscientists (node 1) studying the science of learning; rehabilitation researchers (node 2) working with individuals who benefit from brain training; and computer scientists (node 3) who know how to build computer software that is fun to use. The Engaging Learning Network (ELN) will develop a collaborative web encompassing these three nodes of expertise. ELN will extend and apply the neuroscience of learning through training programs that enchant a diversity of users while enhancing their sensory, motor, and/or cognitive function.

The network comprises 24 investigators from 15 institutions: 10 neuroscientists, 9 rehabilitation researchers, and 5 computer scientists. Collaborations will be built through a scientific meeting, seed projects, graduate student exchanges, and a web portal. The annual scientific meeting will engage members of all ELN laboratories as well as others from outside the network to promote multi-disciplinary research on the art of designing captivating training programs that enable us to study neural plasticity using programs that enhance human function. Results will be disseminated through scientific meetings and the web. Once vetted through peer review, many participants will make sensori-motor training applications commercially available; these synergistic efforts will enhance the real-world impact of the network activities and leverage the basic science supported by the project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Engaging Learning Network extended and applied the neuroscience of learning through games that  enhance sensory, motor, and/or cognitive function. The purpose of the Engaging Learning Network (ELN) was to bring together researchers from a range of disciplines in order to develop captivating, interactive games for the study of sensory, perceptual, sensorimotor, and cognitive learning. We created a network of researchers who want to develop and/or use engrossing, high-quality video games to study neural and cognitive plasticity in both typical and clinical populations. Through the life of the project, we held an annual scientific meeting that provided an interdisciplinary scientific venue for sharing cutting-edge research about learning and gaming. We supported seed projects to initiate pilot inter-disciplinary collaborations across member laboratories in our network. These networking activities were designed to foster a new, interactive and collaborative community.

We brought together neuroscience researchers, rehabilitation researchers, computer programmers, game designers, and game developers. Neuroscience researchers and rehabilitation researchers have now made partnerships that allow them to develop professional, engaging games that deliver evidence-based training protocols to participants-- in a way that promises to keep the participants "working" to improve because it is fun, all in a research platform that provides metrics and measures to the researchers. This is enabling new forms of research on the Science of Learning. Conversely, game developers and designers now have seen how to apply their skills to create games that actually improve human quality of life. They understand the potential of their work to go beyond simple entertainment, to actually changing the world.

The success of our network can be seen in the numerous self-sustaining research collaborations that grew as a result. One group is building games to train auditory perception in children with autism, funded by the Department of Defense. Another group is producing free online games developed for iPhone and iPad to train memory, attention, and auditory perception using evidence-based neuroscience research, funded by the National Institutes of Health. Yet another has created an annual meeting exploring learning and cognitive processing in the auditory system, a meeting that is receiving support from National Institute for Deafness and Other Communication Disorders. Another group of researchers from Europe and the United States has received funding from the European Unionto explore learning in multisensory processing, and will be holding an annual meeting on this topic. A group of early career researchers who met through the network is now working on basic research to understand learning and development of hearing in young children, work that is supported by a grant from the European Union. These are just a few of the examples of the collaborations that exist as a direct outcome of our networking project.

In addition to these clear, concrete examples of sustainable research programs, we provided the trainees from the many laboratories that were involved in our network with unusually broad, cross-displinary perspectives. The trainees who participated in our network came from traditional, disciplinary laboratories. But the experiences they gained were unique This interdisciplinary exposure the network provided altered their trajectories, showing them how to embed basic science in game development, and how to translate basic scientific knowledge about the value of training and learning into an engaging, fun software platform. The explicit connections our trainees made with their peers in other disciplines has lead to ongoing collaborative networks that will enable them to do cutting-edge integrative research as they establish their own independent laboratories in academia or in industry. Neuroscience and rehabilitation trainees now understand some of the key issues in taking their applications into a software game that engages participants and patients. Software developers and game designers in training now have seen the kinds of sensory, motor, and perceptual problems that lend themselves to being addressed by a training game.
